htmlEmbed:
Crypto.com Suffers Hack for At Least $15M in EthereumAndrew Asmakov0/18/2022

The crypto exchange has reportedly lost at least $15 million in Ethereum, and security experts believe the true losses could be much higher.

Business, crypto.com, cryptocurrencies, ETH, Ethereum, Exchanges, hacks, security, NewsRead

<p class="font-meta-serif-pro font-normal text-lg sm:text-xl sm:leading-9 tracking-px text-body">With almost $3 billion in trading volume in the last 24 hours, Crypto.com is the industry’s fourth-largest centralized crypto exchange, according to <a href="https://www.coingecko.com/en/exchanges/crypto_com" target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="sc-adb616fe-0 kVliVL">CoinGecko</a>.</p>
<p class="font-meta-serif-pro font-normal text-lg sm:text-xl sm:leading-9 tracking-px text-body">A household name in Asian markets, the Singapore-based exchange recently <a href="https://decrypt.co/86267/crypto-com-pays-700-million-naming-rights-lakers-clippers-arena-reports" target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="sc-adb616fe-0 kVliVL">spent $700 million</a> to buy the naming rights to the Staples Center—the Los Angeles home venue of the NBA's Lakers and Clippers.</p>
<!-- -->
<p class="font-meta-serif-pro font-normal text-lg sm:text-xl sm:leading-9 tracking-px text-body">On Monday, Crypto.com announced it was pausing withdrawals after “a small number of users experienced unauthorized activity in their accounts,” stressing that “all funds are safe.”</p>
<p class="font-meta-serif-pro font-normal text-lg sm:text-xl sm:leading-9 tracking-px text-body">Citing the need to enhance security, the exchange also urged users to sign back into their accounts and reset their two-factor authentication (2FA).</p>
<div class="relative w-full"><blockquote class="twitter-tweet mx-auto">
<p lang="en" dir="ltr">1/2<br />Earlier today a small number of users experienced unauthorized activity in their accounts. All funds are safe.</p>
<p>In an abundance of caution, security on all accounts is being enhanced, requiring users to:</p>
<p>-Sign back into their App & Exchange accounts<br />-Reset their 2FA</p>
<p>— Crypto.com (@cryptocom) <a href="https://twitter.com/cryptocom/status/1483050866894868484?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw" data-wpel-link="internal">January 17, 2022</a></p></blockquote></div>
<p class="font-meta-serif-pro font-normal text-lg sm:text-xl sm:leading-9 tracking-px text-body"></p>
<h2 style="margin-top:2em;text-align:left;padding-bottom:16px;margin-bottom:16px;border-bottom:1px solid #EBEBEB" color="#333" class="sc-e93b592e-2 dsiLcY">Unpacking the Crypto.com hack</h2>
<p class="font-meta-serif-pro font-normal text-lg sm:text-xl sm:leading-9 tracking-px text-body">Despite users <a href="https://twitter.com/BENBALLER/status/1482955116416172033" target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="sc-adb616fe-0 kVliVL">complaining</a> about funds missing from their accounts, and Dogecoin co-founder Billy Markus <a href="https://twitter.com/BillyM2k/status/1482977279160451075" target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="sc-adb616fe-0 kVliVL">pointing to</a> “odd activity” on one of the Ethereum wallets associated with Crypto.com, the exchange announced that withdrawals had resumed at 17:42 UTC on Monday.</p>
<p class="font-meta-serif-pro font-normal text-lg sm:text-xl sm:leading-9 tracking-px text-body">The events took a turn for the worse when security research company Peckshield took to Twitter in the early hours on Tuesday to reveal that Crypto.com has lost at least 4,600 ETH (around $15 million in current prices).</p>
<p class="font-meta-serif-pro font-normal text-lg sm:text-xl sm:leading-9 tracking-px text-body">Peckshield added that half of the stolen funds were sent to Tornado Cash, the Ethereum-centric mixing service.</p>
<div class="relative w-full"><blockquote class="twitter-tweet mx-auto">
<p lang="en" dir="ltr">The <a href="https://twitter.com/cryptocom?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw" data-wpel-link="internal">@cryptocom</a> loss is about $15M with at least 4.6K ETHs and half of them are currently being washed via <a href="https://twitter.com/TornadoCash?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw" data-wpel-link="internal">@TornadoCash</a> <a href="https://t.co/PUl6IrB3cp" data-wpel-link="internal">https://t.co/PUl6IrB3cp</a> <a href="https://t.co/6SVKvk8PLf" data-wpel-link="internal">https://t.co/6SVKvk8PLf</a> <a href="https://t.co/XN9nmT857j" data-wpel-link="internal">pic.twitter.com/XN9nmT857j</a></p>
<p>— PeckShield Inc. (@peckshield) <a href="https://twitter.com/peckshield/status/1483246262371557378?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw" data-wpel-link="internal">January 18, 2022</a></p></blockquote></div>
<p class="font-meta-serif-pro font-normal text-lg sm:text-xl sm:leading-9 tracking-px text-body"></p>
<p class="font-meta-serif-pro font-normal text-lg sm:text-xl sm:leading-9 tracking-px text-body">Peckshield told <i>Decrypt</i> via a Twitter message that the true scale of the damage is “definitely worse.”</p>
<p class="font-meta-serif-pro font-normal text-lg sm:text-xl sm:leading-9 tracking-px text-body">Quite remarkably, a few hours later, Crypto.com CEO Kris Marszalek said that no customer funds were lost.</p>
<p class="font-meta-serif-pro font-normal text-lg sm:text-xl sm:leading-9 tracking-px text-body">According to Marszalek, the exchange “has hardened the infrastructure in response to the incident” and “will share a full post mortem after the internal investigation is completed.”</p>
<div class="relative w-full"><blockquote class="twitter-tweet mx-auto">
<p lang="en" dir="ltr">Some thoughts from me on the last 24 hours:</p>
<p>- no customer funds were lost <br />- the downtime of withdrawal infra was ~14 hours <br />- our team has hardened the infrastructure in response to the incident</p>
<p>We will share a full post mortem after the internal investigation is completed.</p>
<p>— Kris | Crypto.com (@Kris_HK) <a href="https://twitter.com/Kris_HK/status/1483277350683185155?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw" data-wpel-link="internal">January 18, 2022</a></p></blockquote></div>
<p class="font-meta-serif-pro font-normal text-lg sm:text-xl sm:leading-9 tracking-px text-body"></p>
<p class="font-meta-serif-pro font-normal text-lg sm:text-xl sm:leading-9 tracking-px text-body">It’s worth noting, though, that some users <a href="https://twitter.com/BENBALLER/status/1483188044781928449" target="_blank" rel="noopener" class="sc-adb616fe-0 kVliVL">confirmed</a> that the funds they claimed were missing were eventually returned to their accounts.</p>
<p class="font-meta-serif-pro font-normal text-lg sm:text-xl sm:leading-9 tracking-px text-body"><i>Decrypt</i> has also reached to Crypto.com for comments and will update the story should we hear back.</p>

security, the exchange also urged users to sign back into their accounts and reset their two-factor authentication (2FA).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\"\u003e\n\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\"\u003e1/2\u003cbr /\u003eEarlier today a small number of users experienced unauthorized activity in their accounts. charset=\"utf-8\"\u003e\u003c/script\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eUnpacking the Crypto.com hack\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDespite users \u003ca to\u003c/a\u003e “odd activity” on one of the Ethereum wallets associated with Crypto.com, the exchange announced that withdrawals had resumed at 17:42 UTC on Monday.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe href=\"https://twitter.com/TornadoCash?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\"\u003e@TornadoCash\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href=\"https://t.co/PUl6IrB3cp\" exchange Crypto.com has reportedly fallen victim to a hack, with at least $15 million worth of Ethereum stolen.\n\nDespite reports of missing funds, the platform has yet to confirm that it has indeed been attacked.\n\nWith almost $3 billion in trading volume in the last 24 hours, Crypto.com is the industry’s fourth-largest centralized crypto exchange, according to CoinGecko.\n\nA household name in Asian markets, the Singapore-based exchange recently spent $700 million to buy the naming rights to the Staples Center—the Los Angeles home venue of the NBA's Lakers and Clippers.\n\nCrypto.com Pays Reported $700 Million for Naming Rights to Lakers, Clippers Arena\nOn Monday, Crypto.com announced it was pausing withdrawals after “a small number of users experienced unauthorized activity in their accounts,” stressing that “all funds are safe.”\n\nCiting the need to enhance security, the exchange also urged users to sign back into their accounts and reset their two-factor authentication (2FA).\n\n\u003e 1/2\n\u003e Earlier today a small number of users experienced unauthorized activity in their accounts. All funds are safe.\n\u003e \n\u003e In an abundance of caution, security on all accounts is being enhanced, requiring users to:\n\u003e \n\u003e -Sign back into their App \u0026 Exchange accounts\n\u003e -Reset their 2FA\n\u003e \n\u003e — Crypto.com (@cryptocom) January 17, 2022\n\nUNPACKING THE CRYPTO.COM HACK\n\nDespite users complaining about funds missing from their accounts, and Dogecoin co-founder Billy Markus pointing to “odd activity” on one of the Ethereum wallets associated with Crypto.com, the exchange announced that withdrawals had resumed at 17:42 UTC on Monday.\n\nThe events took a turn for the worse when security research company Peckshield took to Twitter in the early hours on Tuesday to reveal that Crypto.com has lost at least 4,600 ETH (around $15 million in current prices).\n\nPeckshield added that half of the stolen funds were sent to Tornado Cash, the Ethereum-centric mixing service.\n\n\u003e The @cryptocom loss is about $15M with at least 4.6K ETHs and half of them are currently being washed via @TornadoCash https://t.co/PUl6IrB3cp https://t.co/6SVKvk8PLf pic.twitter.com/XN9nmT857j\n\u003e \n\u003e — PeckShield Inc. (@peckshield) January 18, 2022\n\nPeckshield told _Decrypt_ via a Twitter message that the true scale of the damage is “definitely worse.”\n\nQuite remarkably, a few hours later, Crypto.com CEO Kris Marszalek said that no customer funds were lost.\n\nAccording to Marszalek, the exchange “has hardened the infrastructure in response to the incident” and “will share a full post mortem after the internal investigation is completed.”\n\n\u003e Some thoughts from me on the last 24 hours:\n\u003e \n\u003e - no customer funds were lost \n\u003e - the downtime of withdrawal infra was ~14 hours \n\u003e - our team has hardened the infrastructure in response to the incident\n\u003e \n\u003e We will share a full post mortem after the internal investigation is completed.\n\u003e \n\u003e — Kris | Crypto.com (@Kris_HK) January 18, 2022\n\nIt’s worth noting, though, that some users confirmed that the funds they claimed were missing were eventually returned to their accounts.\n\n_Decrypt_ has also reached to Crypto.com for comments and will update the story should we hear back.\n","read_this_next_post_id":90545,"read_this_next_post_type":"post","social_share_img_url":"https://cdn.decrypt.co/resize/1024/height/512/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/hacker-bitcoin-gID_4.jpg","featured_image_caption":"Hacking attacks are a persistent problem for the crypto industry. Belarus Economic Sanctions Apply to Crypto: European Commission"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eThe European Commission \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_22_1649\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003ehas said\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e cryptocurrencies are captured by targeted sanctions adopted by the EU in response to the conflict in Ukraine—as well as Belarus’ role in facilitating Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e“For Belarus, the measures introduce SWIFT prohibitions similar to those in the Russia regime, clarify that crypto assets fall under the scope of ‘transferable securities’ and further expand the existing financial restrictions by mirroring the measures already in place regarding Russia sanctions,” said the Commission. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eThe Commission also “confirmed the common understanding that loans and credit can be provided by any means, including crypto assets, as well as further clarified the notion of ‘transferable securities,’ so as to clearly include crypto assets, and thus ensure the proper implementation of the restrictions in place.”\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eWhat do these sanctions do? \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eThe Commission’s new measures impose restrictions on 160 individuals, including 14 oligarchs and businesspeople involved in key Russian economic sectors. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eIn Belarus, these measures restrict the provision of SWIFT to several key Belarusian banks and prohibit transactions with the Central Bank of Belarus. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eWhat’s more, these restrictions prohibit the listing and provision of services in relation to shares of Belarus state-owned entities on EU trading venues (as of April 12, 2022), prohibit the provision of euro-denominated banknotes to Belarus, and “significantly limit” the financial inflows from Belarus to the EU. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eWhen it comes to Russia, the amended measures introduce new restrictions on maritime navigation and radio technology exports. It also adds the Russian Maritime Register of Shipping to the list of state-owned enterprises subject to restrictions. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eOf course, these sanctions build upon an already widespread and sweeping list of sanctions applied by not only the EU, but the United States, the United Kingdom, and others. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eSanctions have also hit the Central Bank of Russia, key political Russian officials, and much of the Russian State Duma—one of the chambers of the Russian parliament. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eTrade and investment restrictions are also in place in Donetsk and Luhansk. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"ad-unit\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eSanctions and the role of crypto\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eThis is not the first time the crypto industry has been cited as a potential means of sanctions evasion for Russia—or Belarus for that matter. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eIn the wake of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine—which began on February 24, 2022—a plethora of public officials ranging from the \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://decrypt.co/93985/ukrainian-vice-prime-minister-calls-on-crypto-exchanges-to-ban-russian-users\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eUkrainian Vice Prime Minister\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e to the \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://decrypt.co/94368/japan-assess-russia-sanctions-using-crypto\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eJapanese financial services regulator\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e have turned their attention to this risk. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eFrance’s Finance Minister, Bruno le Maire, also \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://decrypt.co/94280/eu-taking-measures-prevent-russia-evading-sanctions-crypto-le-maire\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003erecently said\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e the EU was “taking measures” to ensure Russia doesn’t evade sanctions using crypto. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eIn the United States, the U.S. Treasury \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://decrypt.co/94108/treasury-ofac-crack-down-crypto-transactions-russia\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003erecently announced\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e new rules that built on an existing executive order to crack down on cryptocurrency-related efforts to evade sanctions. These rules take aim at “deceptive or structured transactions or dealings to circumvent any United States sanctions, including through the use of digital currencies.” \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eLast October, the Treasury also took aim at this issue, \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://decrypt.co/83779/digital-assets-weaken-us-sanctions-regime-treasury-dept\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003epublishing a report\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e that said cryptocurrencies could undermine the broader American sanctions regime. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"embedded-post\" data-id=\"rYzaFLgp\" data-post-title=\"\" data-post-type=\"post\" data-post-orientation=\"horizontal\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eAll of this concern surrounds the \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://decrypt.co/93795/how-russia-could-use-crypto-to-evade-sanctions-following-ukraine-invasion\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003emultiple ways\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e in which cryptocurrencies can help facilitate sanctions evasion. One such method is through the use of ransomware—an illicit industry that Russia profited from more than any other nation-state in 2021, per \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://blog.chainalysis.com/reports/2022-crypto-crime-report-preview-russia-ransomware-money-laundering/\" data-wpel-link=\"external\" rel=\"nofollow external noopener\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eChainalysis research\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eCrane Hassold, former FBI agent and current Director of Threat Intelligence at Abnormal Security, recently told \u003c/span\u003e\u003ci\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eDecrypt\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/i\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e cryptocurrencies were the “primary factor” driving today’s ransomware industry. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eElsewhere, Russia may pivot to \u003cspan class=\"link\"\u003e\u003ca alt=\"bitcoin news\" href=\"/resources/what-is-bitcoin-four-minute-instant-guide-explainer\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\"\u003eBitcoin\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e mining—which President Putin has previously said Russia has a “competitive advantage” in—or the use of non-compliant exchanges, a strategy that Russian criminals have used before. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e“We’ve seen instances before of crypto asset exchange services that were complicit in enabling Russia-based criminals to launder large amounts of money…one was called SUEX,” said David Carlisle, Director of Policy and Regulatory Affairs at blockchain analytics firm Elliptic during a recent online webinar. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eIn September 2021, the U.S. Treasury’s Office of Foreign Assets Control \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0364\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003esanctioned SUEX\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e pursuant to Executive Order 13694, which authorized the imposition of sanctions on those complicit in cyber-related activity against the interests of the United States. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003cp\u003eThe European Commission has said cryptocurrencies are also included in the sanctions package applied twitter-description":"","twitter-image":null},"authors":[]}}],"link":[]},"content_text":"The European Commission has said cryptocurrencies are captured by targeted sanctions adopted by the EU in response to the conflict in Ukraine—as well as Belarus’ role in facilitating Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. \n\n“For Belarus, the measures introduce SWIFT prohibitions similar to those in the Russia regime, clarify that crypto assets fall under the scope of ‘transferable securities’ and further expand the existing financial restrictions by mirroring the measures already in place regarding Russia sanctions,” said the Commission. \n\nThe Commission also “confirmed the common understanding that loans and credit can be provided by any means, including crypto assets, as well as further clarified the notion of ‘transferable securities,’ so as to clearly include crypto assets, and thus ensure the proper implementation of the restrictions in place.”\n\nWHAT DO THESE SANCTIONS DO? \n\nThe Commission’s new measures impose restrictions on 160 individuals, including 14 oligarchs and businesspeople involved in key Russian economic sectors. \n\nIn Belarus, these measures restrict the provision of SWIFT to several key Belarusian banks and prohibit transactions with the Central Bank of Belarus. \n\nWhat’s more, these restrictions prohibit the listing and provision of services in relation to shares of Belarus state-owned entities on EU trading venues (as of April 12, 2022), prohibit the provision of euro-denominated banknotes to Belarus, and “significantly limit” the financial inflows from Belarus to the EU. \n\nWhen it comes to Russia, the amended measures introduce new restrictions on maritime navigation and radio technology exports. It also adds the Russian Maritime Register of Shipping to the list of state-owned enterprises subject to restrictions. \n\nOf course, these sanctions build upon an already widespread and sweeping list of sanctions applied by not only the EU, but the United States, the United Kingdom, and others. \n\nSanctions have also hit the Central Bank of Russia, key political Russian officials, and much of the Russian State Duma—one of the chambers of the Russian parliament. \n\nTrade and investment restrictions are also in place in Donetsk and Luhansk. \n\nSANCTIONS AND THE ROLE OF CRYPTO\n\nThis is not the first time the crypto industry has been cited as a potential means of sanctions evasion for Russia—or Belarus for that matter. \n\nIn the wake of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine—which began on February 24, 2022—a plethora of public officials ranging from the Ukrainian Vice Prime Minister to the Japanese financial services regulator have turned their attention to this risk. \n\nFrance’s Finance Minister, Bruno le Maire, also recently said the EU was “taking measures” to ensure Russia doesn’t evade sanctions using crypto. \n\nIn the United States, the U.S. Treasury recently announced new rules that built on an existing executive order to crack down on cryptocurrency-related efforts to evade sanctions. These rules take aim at “deceptive or structured transactions or dealings to circumvent any United States sanctions, including through the use of digital currencies.” \n\nLast October, the Treasury also took aim at this issue, publishing a report that said cryptocurrencies could undermine the broader American sanctions regime. \n\nAll of this concern surrounds the multiple ways in which cryptocurrencies can help facilitate sanctions evasion. One such method is through the use of ransomware—an illicit industry that Russia profited from more than any other nation-state in 2021, per Chainalysis research. \n\nCrane Hassold, former FBI agent and current Director of Threat Intelligence at Abnormal Security, recently told _Decrypt_ cryptocurrencies were the “primary factor” driving today’s ransomware industry. \n\nElsewhere, Russia may pivot to Bitcoin mining—which President Putin has previously said Russia has a “competitive advantage” in—or the use of non-compliant exchanges, a strategy that Russian criminals have used before. \n\n“We’ve seen instances before of crypto asset exchange services that were complicit in enabling Russia-based criminals to launder large amounts of money…one was called SUEX,” said David Carlisle, Director of Policy and Regulatory Affairs at blockchain analytics firm Elliptic during a recent online webinar. \n\nIn September 2021, the U.S. Treasury’s Office of Foreign Assets Control sanctioned SUEX pursuant to Executive Order 13694, which authorized the imposition of sanctions on those complicit in cyber-related activity against the interests of the United States. \n","read_this_next_post_id":94692,"read_this_next_post_type":"post","social_share_img_url":"https://cdn.decrypt.co/resize/1024/height/512/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/european-commission-crypto-belarus-russia-gID_1.jpg","featured_image_caption":"The European Commission is the EU's executive branch. Image: Shutterstock. ","featured_image_description":"The European Commission is the EU's executive branch. Image: Shutterstock. Biden Signs Long-Awaited Crypto Executive Order"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003ePresident Biden has today \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/presidential-actions/2022/03/09/executive-order-on-ensuring-responsible-development-of-digital-assets/\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003esigned\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e the Executive Order on Ensuring Responsible Development of Digital Assets.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eThis executive order is the first \"whole-of-government\" approach to regulating the cryptocurrency industry, and it aims to target a plethora of issues within the crypto space, including consumer protection, illicit finance, financial inclusion, and \"responsible development.\"\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e\"Growing development and adoption of digital assets and related innovations, as well as inconsistent controls to defend against certain key risks, necessitate an evolution and alignment of the United States Government approach to digital assets,\" the executive order reads.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eCrucially, today’s executive order does not itself introduce new regulations or provide regulatory agencies with the administration’s position on what regulations, specifically, they ought to adopt. Rather, the order asks for federal agencies, such as the Federal Trade Commission, the SEC, and the CFTC, to coordinate their efforts with respect to their oversight of the crypto industry. It also calls for the Treasury Department to “produce a report on the future of money and payment systems.”\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cb\u003eWhat’s in Biden’s crypto executive order\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003ePresident Biden’s crypto executive order is broken down into 10 sections: policy, objectives, coordination, central bank digital currencies, consumer protection, financial stability, actions to address illicit finance in digital assets, international cooperation, definitions, and finally, general provisions. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eUnder section two—\"Objectives\"—the executive order lays out six key objective aims of the government as it pertains to digital assets. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"ad-unit\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eFront and center is the need to protect \"consumers, investors, and businesses in the United States.\" \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e\"The unique and varied features of digital assets can pose significant financial risks to consumers, investors, and businesses if appropriate protections are not in place,\" the executive order reads, echoing similar warnings made frequently by Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Gary Gensler. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eThe second risk references protecting the U.S. from global financial instability, pointing out that the rapidly growing digital asset trading platform industry \"may not be subject to or in compliance with appropriate regulations or supervision.\" \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eThird, the executive order points to the \"illicit finance and national security risks posed by misuse of digital assets.\" \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eBiden’s order lists several illicit finance risks associated with cryptocurrency, including money laundering, cybercrime, ransomware, narcotics, human trafficking, and terrorism financing. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eIn recent weeks, the crypto industry has been under renewed scrutiny amid fears that Russia could use cryptocurrencies to \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://decrypt.co/93795/how-russia-could-use-crypto-to-evade-sanctions-following-ukraine-invasion\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eevade economic sanctions\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e, though there are individuals within the crypto industry that dispute this perspective. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cblockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\"\u003e\n\u003cp lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\"\u003e1/ Russia can\u0026#39;t \u0026amp; won\u0026#39;t use crypto to evade sanctions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eConcerns about crypto\u0026#39;s use for sanctions evasion are totally unfounded. They fundamentally misunderstand:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e- how sanctions work\u003cbr /\u003e- how crypto markets work\u003cbr /\u003e- how Putin is actually trying to mitigate sanctions\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI\u0026#39;ll explain 🧵\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u0026mdash; Jake Chervinsky (@jchervinsky) \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/jchervinsky/status/1498786025438650369?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\"\u003eMarch 1, 2022\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cscript async src=\"https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"\u003e\u003c/script\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eRounding off the six key objectives, the executive order commits the U.S. to reinforcing its leadership in technology, promoting access to safe and affordable financial services, and supporting \"responsible development.\" \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eIn a prepared statement published by Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen—before the executive order was signed—Yellen praised the government's commitment to \"responsible development.\"\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e\"This approach will support responsible innovation that could result in substantial benefits for the nation, consumers, and businesses,\" Yellen said in her statement, which can be accessed via the WayBack Machine \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://web.archive.org/web/20220309014601/https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy0643\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\"\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003ehere\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\u003cb\u003eWhat about the climate?\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eWhile the crypto industry's climate impact does not earn a specifically dedicated section, the U.S. government is taking this issue seriously, too. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eWithin 180 days of the order, Biden has instructed multiple leading authorities—including the Environmental Protection Agency—to submit a report to the president that will examine the \"potential for these technologies to impede or advance efforts to tackle climate change at home and abroad.\" \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eSpecifically, proof-of-work blockchain mechanisms like Bitcoin's may come under fire. These blockchains are secured by high-end computers which perform complex mathematical calculations—which, consequently, demand a high consumption of energy. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eOther networks—such as proof-of-stake blockchains \u003cspan class=\"link\"\u003e\u003ca alt=\"\" href=\"https://decrypt.co/resources/what-is-avalanche-network-avax-ava-labs\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\"\u003eAvalanche\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e and \u003cspan class=\"link\"\u003e\u003ca alt=\"what is solana\" href=\"https://decrypt.co/resources/what-is-solana-a-scalable-decentralized-network-for-dapps\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\"\u003eSolana\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e—do not require the same amount of energy consumption, and thus have smaller carbon footprints. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eAccording to the order, \"The report should also address the effect of cryptocurrencies' consensus mechanisms on energy usage, including research into potential mitigating measures and alternative measures of Launched in January 2009, it was the world’s first cryptocurrency, and remains the most popular, with the highest market capitalization of all cryptocurrencies.\u003c/span\u003e\r\n\r\nBitcoin was built on several key innovations. Firstly, Nakamoto guaranteed that Bitcoin transactions were immutable, by recording all transactions on a distributed ledger known as a blockchain. Secondly, he ensured Bitcoin’s scarcity by capping the total number of Bitcoin in existence at 21 million. ors":[]}},{"term_id":36631,"name":"Executive Order","slug":"executive-order","term_group":0,"term_taxonomy_id":36631,"taxonomy":"post_tag","description":"","parent":0,"count":4,"filter":"raw","custom_fields":{"i18n":{"hreflang_items":[],"language":{"language_code":"en","locale":"en_US","text_direction":false,"display_name":"English","native_name":"English","different_language":false}},"yoast":{"metatitle":"","metadesc":"","focuskw":null,"linkdex":null,"metakeywords":null,"meta-robots-noindex":null,"meta-robots-nofollow":null,"canonical":null,"redirect":null,"opengraph-title":"","opengraph-description":"","opengraph-image":null,"twitter-title":"","twitter-description":"","twitter-image":null},"authors":[]}}],"link":[]},"content_text":"President Biden has today signed the Executive Order on Ensuring Responsible Development of Digital Assets.\n\nThis executive order is the first \"whole-of-government\" approach to regulating the cryptocurrency industry, and it aims to target a plethora of issues within the crypto space, including consumer protection, illicit finance, financial inclusion, and \"responsible development.\"\n\n\"Growing development and adoption of digital assets and related innovations, as well as inconsistent controls to defend against certain key risks, necessitate an evolution and alignment of the United States Government approach to digital assets,\" the executive order reads.\n\nCrucially, today’s executive order does not itself introduce new regulations or provide regulatory agencies with the administration’s position on what regulations, specifically, they ought to adopt. Rather, the order asks for federal agencies, such as the Federal Trade Commission, the SEC, and the CFTC, to coordinate their efforts with respect to their oversight of the crypto industry. It also calls for the Treasury Department to “produce a report on the future of money and payment systems.”\n\nWHAT’S IN BIDEN’S CRYPTO EXECUTIVE ORDER\n\nPresident Biden’s crypto executive order is broken down into 10 sections: policy, objectives, coordination, central bank digital currencies, consumer protection, financial stability, actions to address illicit finance in digital assets, international cooperation, definitions, and finally, general provisions. \n\nUnder section two—\"Objectives\"—the executive order lays out six key objective aims of the government as it pertains to digital assets. \n\nFront and center is the need to protect \"consumers, investors, and businesses in the United States.\" \n\n\"The unique and varied features of digital assets can pose significant financial risks to consumers, investors, and businesses if appropriate protections are not in place,\" the executive order reads, echoing similar warnings made frequently by Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Gary Gensler. \n\nThe second risk references protecting the U.S. from global financial instability, pointing out that the rapidly growing digital asset trading platform industry \"may not be subject to or in compliance with appropriate regulations or supervision.\" \n\nThird, the executive order points to the \"illicit finance and national security risks posed by misuse of digital assets.\" \n\nBiden’s order lists several illicit finance risks associated with cryptocurrency, including money laundering, cybercrime, ransomware, narcotics, human trafficking, and terrorism financing. \n\nIn recent weeks, the crypto industry has been under renewed scrutiny amid fears that Russia could use cryptocurrencies to evade economic sanctions, though there are individuals within the crypto industry that dispute this perspective. \n\n\u003e 1/ Russia can't \u0026 won't use crypto to evade sanctions.\n\u003e \n\u003e Concerns about crypto's use for sanctions evasion are totally unfounded. They fundamentally misunderstand:\n\u003e \n\u003e - how sanctions work\n\u003e - how crypto markets work\n\u003e - how Putin is actually trying to mitigate sanctions\n\u003e \n\u003e I'll explain 🧵\n\u003e \n\u003e — Jake Chervinsky (@jchervinsky) March 1, 2022\n\nRounding off the six key objectives, the executive order commits the U.S. to reinforcing its leadership in technology, promoting access to safe and affordable financial services, and supporting \"responsible development.\" \n\nIn a prepared statement published by Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen—before the executive order was signed—Yellen praised the government's commitment to \"responsible development.\"\n\n\"This approach will support responsible innovation that could result in substantial benefits for the nation, consumers, and businesses,\" Yellen said in her statement, which can be accessed via the WayBack Machine here. \n\nWHAT ABOUT THE CLIMATE?\n\nWhile the crypto industry's climate impact does not earn a specifically dedicated section, the U.S. government is taking this issue seriously, too. \n\nWithin 180 days of the order, Biden has instructed multiple leading authorities—including the Environmental Protection Agency—to submit a report to the president that will examine the \"potential for these technologies to impede or advance efforts to tackle climate change at home and abroad.\" \n\nSpecifically, proof-of-work blockchain mechanisms like Bitcoin's may come under fire. These blockchains are secured by high-end computers which perform complex mathematical calculations—which, consequently, demand a high consumption of energy. \n\nOther networks—such as proof-of-stake blockchains Avalanche and Solana—do not require the same amount of energy consumption, and thus have smaller carbon footprints. \n\nAccording to the order, \"The report should also address the effect of cryptocurrencies' consensus mechanisms on energy usage, including research into potential mitigating measures and alternative measures of consensus.\" \n","read_this_next_post_id":94685,"read_this_next_post_type":"post","social_share_img_url":"https://cdn.decrypt.co/resize/1024/height/512/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/joe-biden-democratic-presidential-candidate-gID_4.jpg","featured_image_caption":"Image: Taps Polygon to Scale NFT Functionality in Behance Social Platform"},"content":{"rendered":"\u003cp\u003eAdobe, a leading software company, announced today that it's working with Polygon to integrate the Ethereum scaling program into its \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/Behance\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\"\u003eBehance\u003c/a\u003e social media platform.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe integration, according to \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/0xPolygon\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\"\u003ePolygon\u003c/a\u003e, will allow creators to showcase non-fungible tokens to the world while minimizing their carbon footprint and transaction fees. \u003ca class=\"sc-adb616fe-0 kVliVL\" href=\"https://decrypt.co/resources/non-fungible-tokens-nfts-explained-guide-learn-blockchain\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\"\u003eNFTs\u003c/a\u003e are unique tokens that exist on a blockchain and signify ownership of an asset.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAdobe acquired Behance in December 2012. In October, Behance began integrating tools for digital artists to create NFTs—around the same time Polygon began its integration with the top NFT marketplace, OpenSea. According to Polygon, creators can now mint NFTs directly on the Polygon network to OpenSea, bypassing the Ethereum network.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://decrypt.co/resources/what-is-polygon-matic-and-why-it-matters-for-ethereum\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\"\u003ePolygon\u003c/a\u003e, formerly Matic Network, is a Proof-of-Stake (PoS) protocol launched in October 2017 as a way for Ethereum-compatible blockchains to solve scaling challenges. Polygon’s native coin, MATIC, is the 16th-largest cryptocurrency by market capitalization as of this writing, at nearly \u003ca href=\"https://coinmarketcap.com/currencies/polygon/\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\"\u003e$11.2 billion\u003c/a\u003e, according to CoinMarketCap.com. Polygon uses MATIC for payments and settlements.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"ad-unit\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e“I love Polygon’s vision of being an Ethereum scaling solution,” Will Allen, Adobe’s vice president of product, told \u003cem\u003eDecrypt\u003c/em\u003e in an email. “It can help give creators the best of both worlds: the security of Ethereum as a settlement layer while providing lower gas fees and a negligible carbon footprint.”\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAllen said artists can mint NFTs wherever they’d like, either on their contract or via OpenSea, adding that on Behance creatives can showcase their work by connecting their MetaMask wallets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"embedded-post\" data-id=\"94551\" data-post-title=\"DraftKings Co-Founder Says Becoming Polygon Validator Helps 'Futureproof' Company\" data-post-type=\"post\" data-post-orientation=\"horizontal\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://wp.decrypt.co/94551/draftkings-co-founder-becoming-polygon-validator-helps-futureproof-company/\" data-wpel-link=\"internal\"\u003eDraftKings Co-Founder Says Becoming Polygon Validator Helps 'Futureproof' Company\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e“It’s been remarkable to watch the adoption—tens of thousands of users have connected their MetaMask wallets to showcase their NFTs. I’m excited to see this continue to grow,” Allen said.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBehance also plans to roll out tools to help solve some specific problems creatives have encountered in the NFT space, like \u003ca href=\"https://blog.adobe.com/en/publish/2021/10/26/adobe-unleashes-content-attribution-features-photoshop-beyond-max-2021#gs.e525dh\" data-wpel-link=\"external\" rel=\"nofollow external noopener\"\u003eContent Credentials\u003c/a\u003e, which was launched in October to increase transparency and help artists prove ownership.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e“Behance’s mission,” Allen added, “is to help creatives build their careers on their own terms.”\u003c/p\u003e\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"\u003cp\u003eThe integration will allow Behance users to mint directly onto OpenSea while avoiding higher fees on witter-title":"","twitter-description":"","twitter-image":null},"authors":[]}}],"link":[]},"content_text":"Adobe, a leading software company, announced today that it's working with Polygon to integrate the Ethereum scaling program into its Behance social media platform.\n\nThe integration, according to Polygon, will allow creators to showcase non-fungible tokens to the world while minimizing their carbon footprint and transaction fees. NFTs are unique tokens that exist on a blockchain and signify ownership of an asset.\n\nAdobe acquired Behance in December 2012. In October, Behance began integrating tools for digital artists to create NFTs—around the same time Polygon began its integration with the top NFT marketplace, OpenSea. According to Polygon, creators can now mint NFTs directly on the Polygon network to OpenSea, bypassing the Ethereum network.\n\nPolygon, formerly Matic Network, is a Proof-of-Stake (PoS) protocol launched in October 2017 as a way for Ethereum-compatible blockchains to solve scaling challenges. Polygon’s native coin, MATIC, is the 16th-largest cryptocurrency by market capitalization as of this writing, at nearly $11.2 billion, according to CoinMarketCap.com. Polygon uses MATIC for payments and settlements.\n\n“I love Polygon’s vision of being an Ethereum scaling solution,” Will Allen, Adobe’s vice president of product, told _Decrypt_ in an email. “It can help give creators the best of both worlds: the security of Ethereum as a settlement layer while providing lower gas fees and a negligible carbon footprint.”\n\nAllen said artists can mint NFTs wherever they’d like, either on their contract or via OpenSea, adding that on Behance creatives can showcase their work by connecting their MetaMask wallets.\n\nDraftKings Co-Founder Says Becoming Polygon Validator Helps 'Futureproof' Company\n“It’s been remarkable to watch the adoption—tens of thousands of users have connected their MetaMask wallets to showcase their NFTs. I’m excited to see this continue to grow,” Allen said.\n\nBehance also plans to roll out tools to help solve some specific problems creatives have encountered in the NFT space, like Content Credentials, which was launched in October to increase transparency and help artists prove ownership.\n\n“Behance’s mission,” Allen added, “is to help creatives build their careers on their own terms.”\n","read_this_next_post_id":94637,"read_this_next_post_type":"post","social_share_img_url":"https://cdn.decrypt.co/resize/1024/height/512/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/Polygon-Matic-gID_5.jpeg","featured_image_caption":"Polygon. exchange Binance is planning an acquisition spree that will target companies operating in traditional markets, according to the _Financial Times_. \n\n\"We want to identify and invest in one or two targets in every economic sector and try to bring them into crypto,\" Changpeng Zhao, Binance CEO, told the _Financial Times_ during an interview. \n\n\"The strategy is about making the crypto industry bigger,\" he added. \n\nZhao's comments come hot on the heels of the exchange's mammoth $200 million investment in _Forbes_, making the crypto exchange one of the two largest owners of the publisher. This deal, in turn, came just over a year after Binance sued _Forbes_. \n\n\"With Binance's investment in Forbes, we now have the experience, network and resources of the world's leading crypto exchange and one of the world's most successful blockchain innovators,\" Forbes CEO Mike Ferdele said at the time. \n\nIn addition, Zhao's comments come shortly after Binance's most recent clash with the UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA). \n\nBINANCE AND THE FCA\n\nEarlier this week, the FCA announced a $36 million loan from Bifinity—an entity within the wider Binance Group—to Eqonex Limited, the parent company of FCA-registered crypto asset business Digivault Limited. \n\nAs a result of this transaction, the FCA said, \"individuals and entities that are part of the Binance Group may have become beneficial owners of Digivault for the purposes of the Money Laundering Regulations,\"—the regulations the FCA oversees in connection to crypto asset businesses. \n\nLast summer, the FCA told _Decrypt_ it was concerned over the crypto exchange's apparent lack of a headquarters. In September, the regulator doubled down and said Binance Markets Limited, part of Binance Group, was not capable of being regulated—after it failed to provide basic information to the regulator. \n\nThis week, the FCA reiterated its concerns amid the Bifinity and Eqonex deal and said until outstanding issues raised by the FCA are addressed, the regulator's concerns about Binance Markets Limited remain. \n\n\"The FCA can take steps to suspend or cancel the registration of a crypto asset business if it is not satisfied the firm or its beneficial owner is fit and proper,\" the regulator added. Terra’s other token, LUNA, serves as a staking and governance token, letting users vote and make proposals about how the protocol should be improved. \n\nBoth tokens are also deeply interconnected too. \n\nEach time $1 worth of UST is minted, an equivalent amount of LUNA is destroyed. The opposite is also true: In order to create $1 worth of LUNA, users must destroy $1 of UST. This mechanism helps keep UST pegged to the dollar, for whenever it falls below its peg, market participants are incentivized to swap the discounted UST for LUNA. This destroys UST, reduces supply, and, theoretically, pushes the value of UST back to $1. \n\nSo far, it's working too. \n\nDEFI AND STAKING ON TERRA\n\nUST is the crypto market’s largest decentralized stablecoin (meaning it’s not backed by a singular entity nor can its reserves be easily blacklisted or frozen) and the fourth-largest stablecoin overall. \n\nThe largest stablecoins are Tether (USDT) and USD Coin (USDC), each of which commands a market cap of $80 billion and $52 billion, respectively.\n\nAfter sheer price performance, LUNA has also just become the most-staked cryptocurrency, overtaking Ethereum and Solana, according to data pulled from Staking Rewards. Oasis posted overnight gains of 10.4% to hit $0.24, Secret rose 14.5% to hit $4.9, while Horizen jumped 17% to $41.14. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eEven outside the well-known privacy coins, various alternatives are rallying by similar stretches. Pirate Chain is up 18%, Verge is up 24.7% and Dero is up 16.3% – all in the last 24 hours. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003ePrivacy coins vary in method and utility, but broadly speaking, they use cryptographic techniques to obscure identifying information like addresses and transaction amounts from prying eyes.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"price-graph\" data-date-range=1m data-id=6251 data-type=\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: 400;\"\u003eZcash and Monero both use a cryptographic technique called zero-knowledge proofs, which lets users make transactions without specifying any details about the transactions in question, other than the fact that they are legitimate. While Monero only allows for private transactions, Zcash also allows for public ones.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan style=\"font-weight: ":"","twitter-image":null},"authors":[]}}],"link":[]},"content_text":"Top privacy coins like Monero and Zcash are surging in price today, with several of them posting overnight gains of 10 to 20%.\n\nThe largest privacy coin Monero, which has a market capitalization of over $3.5 billion, shot up 18.8% in the last 24 hours and trades for around $195.43. Despite the rise, that’s still about 64% short of its former all-time high of $517, set back in May 2021, according to CoinMarketCap. \n\nZcash is up 17.6% today and trades for $131.87 at the time of writing. Like Monero, it’s still far from recapturing its former all-time high of $5,941, which was set back in October 2016.\n\nOasis, Secret and Horizon, respectively the third-, fourth- and fifth-biggest privacy coins by market capitalization, are also rallying hard. Oasis posted overnight gains of 10.4% to hit $0.24, Secret rose 14.5% to hit $4.9, while Horizen jumped 17% to $41.14. \n\nEven outside the well-known privacy coins, various alternatives are rallying by similar stretches. Pirate Chain is up 18%, Verge is up 24.7% and Dero is up 16.3% – all in the last 24 hours. \n\nPrivacy coins vary in method and utility, but broadly speaking, they use cryptographic techniques to obscure identifying information like addresses and transaction amounts from prying eyes.\n\nZcash and Monero both use a cryptographic technique called zero-knowledge proofs, which lets users make transactions without specifying any details about the transactions in question, other than the fact that they are legitimate. While Monero only allows for private transactions, Zcash also allows for public ones.\n\n​​ \n\nPRIVACY COINS JUMP ON POLITICAL NEWS\n\nAs crypto becomes more mainstream, various governments around the world think now would be a prudent time to start drafting legislation to minimize any potential damage the developing digital economy might have on traditional financial markets. \n\nLegislators are also seeking safeguards for common investors against adverse market movements and actors.\n\nThe Biden administration has just released more details from an executive order from the White House this week to help clarify and coordinate the roles of agencies such as the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) with regards to crypto.\n\nPresident Biden to Sign Crypto Executive Order 'Today': White House\nElsewhere, Elizabeth Warren and three other Democratic senators announced that they would be drafting  a \"new bill to ensure crypto isn't used by Putin and his cronies to undermine our economic sanctions.\" Initial reporting of the new bill indicates that it would \"seek to make it easier\" to identify users who move money between private crypto wallets like MetaMask or WalletConnect.\n\nMeanwhile, Russia’s central bank yesterday banned foreign currency withdrawals of over $10,000 until September 9, to slow the outflow of capital after the international community imposed heavy economic sanctions following Putin’s decision to invade Ukraine. \n\nWith crypto falling under the microscope like never before, market activity suggests that investors may very well be flocking to more privacy-centric cryptocurrencies.\n\nThe views and opinions expressed by the author are for informational purposes only and do not constitute readabilityObject.title: Crypto.com Suffers Hack for At Least $15M in Ethereum
readabilityObject.content:
Cryptocurrency exchange Crypto.com has reportedly fallen victim to a hack, with at least $15 million worth of Ethereum stolen.

Despite reports of missing funds, the platform has yet to confirm that it has indeed been attacked.

With almost $3 billion in trading volume in the last 24 hours, Crypto.com is the industry’s fourth-largest centralized crypto exchange, according to CoinGecko.

A household name in Asian markets, the Singapore-based exchange recently spent $700 million to buy the naming rights to the Staples Center—the Los Angeles home venue of the NBA's Lakers and Clippers.

On Monday, Crypto.com announced it was pausing withdrawals after “a small number of users experienced unauthorized activity in their accounts,” stressing that “all funds are safe.”

Citing the need to enhance security, the exchange also urged users to sign back into their accounts and reset their two-factor authentication (2FA).

1/2
Earlier today a small number of users experienced unauthorized activity in their accounts. All funds are safe.

In an abundance of caution, security on all accounts is being enhanced, requiring users to:

-Sign back into their App & Exchange accounts
-Reset their 2FA

— Crypto.com (@cryptocom) January 17, 2022

Unpacking the Crypto.com hack

Despite users complaining about funds missing from their accounts, and Dogecoin co-founder Billy Markus pointing to “odd activity” on one of the Ethereum wallets associated with Crypto.com, the exchange announced that withdrawals had resumed at 17:42 UTC on Monday.

The events took a turn for the worse when security research company Peckshield took to Twitter in the early hours on Tuesday to reveal that Crypto.com has lost at least 4,600 ETH (around $15 million in current prices).

Peckshield added that half of the stolen funds were sent to Tornado Cash, the Ethereum-centric mixing service.

Peckshield told Decrypt via a Twitter message that the true scale of the damage is “definitely worse.”

Quite remarkably, a few hours later, Crypto.com CEO Kris Marszalek said that no customer funds were lost.

According to Marszalek, the exchange “has hardened the infrastructure in response to the incident” and “will share a full post mortem after the internal investigation is completed.”

Some thoughts from me on the last 24 hours:

- no customer funds were lost
- the downtime of withdrawal infra was ~14 hours
- our team has hardened the infrastructure in response to the incident

We will share a full post mortem after the internal investigation is completed.

— Kris | Crypto.com (@Kris_HK) January 18, 2022

It’s worth noting, though, that some users confirmed that the funds they claimed were missing were eventually returned to their accounts.

Decrypt has also reached to Crypto.com for comments and will update the story should we hear back.

https://decrypt.co/90590/crypto-com-suffers-hack-at-least-15m-ethereum

The best of Decrypt straight to your inbox.

Get the top stories curated daily, weekly roundups & deep dives straight to your inbox.
